introduction.p:
In Activity, we investigated the Taylor polynomials centered at 0 for the function f(x) = \frac{1}{1-x} and found that
T_n(x) = 1 + x + x^2 + x^3 + \cdots + x^n . Moreover, we saw that it is natural to extend the degree n Taylor polynomial to an infinite Taylor series; for f(x) = \frac{1}{1-x}, the corresponding Taylor series is
T(x) = 1 + x + x^2 + x^3 + \cdots x^n + \cdots . Because T(x) is an infinite geometric series with a = 1 and r = x, whenever |r| = |x| \lt 1, the series converges and its sum is
T(x) = 1 + x + x^2 + x^3 + \cdots x^n + \cdots \frac{a}{1-r} = \frac{1}{1-x} = f(x) . Remarkably, this shows that the original function, f(x) = \frac{1}{1-x}, is equal to its Taylor series for all values of x that satisfy |x| \lt 1. So, not only do Taylor polynomials provide increasingly better approximations to a function as the degree n increases, but it appears that if we let n increase without bound we arrive at a new representation of the original function through its Taylor seriesThis new representation may only be valid for a limited set of x-values, such as |x| \lt 1 in the case of f(x) = \frac{1}{1-x}.
In this section, we will find and discuss the Taylor series for several well-known functions. We begin with an infinite geometric series and explore the function to which the series is related.

subsection.title: Taylor series
subsection.p: From our work in Activity and Preview Activity, we have seen two examples where the Taylor polynomials of a given function lead to a corresponding infinite Taylor series that is actually equal to the original function itself. This suggests that Taylor series are important as they can give rise to a polynomial-like representation of a non-polynomial function. We start with the formal definition of the Taylor series of a function.

statement.p:
Let f be a function such that f^{(n)}(a) exists for every natural number n. The Taylor series for f centered at x=a is the series T_f(x) defined by
T_f(x) =\mathstrut \amp \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \frac{f^{(k)}(a)}{k!}(x-a)^k =\mathstrut \amp f(a) + f'(a)(x-a) + \frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x-a)^2 + \cdots + \frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{n!}(x-a)^n + \cdots .

subsection.p:
In the special case where a=0 in Definition, the Taylor series is also sometimes called the Maclaurin series
for f.

From Activity we know the nth order Taylor polynomial centered at 0 for the function f(x) = \frac{1}{1-x} is
T_n(x) = 1 + x + x^2 + \cdots + x^n , and thus the Maclaurin series for f(x) = \frac{1}{1-x} is
T_f(x) = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} x^k . Because this particular series is geometric (with common ratio r = x), we are able to easily find a shortcut formula for its sum and understand the values of x for which the infinite sum makes sense. In particular, for |x| \lt 1,
f(x) = \frac{1}{1-x} = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} x^k = T_f(x) . It turns out that while most Taylor series are not geometric series, we can compare Taylor series to geometric series in order to determine the x-values for which they make sense. To see how we might approach this issue, we consider the following example.

statement.p: State the Taylor series at a = 0 for \ln(1+x), determine whether or not the Taylor series is geometric, and investigate the x-values for which the series appears to converge.

solution.p:
In Example, we found that the general degree n Taylor polynomial centered at a = 0 for f(x) = \ln(1+x) is
T_n(x) = x - \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{3}x^3 - \cdots + (-1)^{n-1}\frac{1}{n}x^n . This pattern thus allows us to see that the Taylor series for f(x), centered at a = 0, is
T_f(x) =\mathstrut \amp \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{n-1}\frac{1}{n}x^n =\mathstrut \amp x - \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{3}x^3 - \cdots + (-1)^{n-1}\frac{1}{n}x^n + \cdots . Next, we determine whether or not this Taylor series is a geometric series.

For a series to be geometric, it must have a constant ratio between the terms. In T_f(x), the general nth term is
a_n(x) = (-1)^{n-1}\frac{1}{n}x^n
so the (n+1)st term is
a_{n+1}(x) = (-1)^{n}\frac{1}{n+1}x^{n+1} . If we consider the ratio of these consecutive terms and call that quantity r_n(x), we find that
r_n(x) = \frac{a_{n+1}(x)}{a_n(x)} = \frac{(-1)^{n}\frac{1}{n+1}x^{n+1}}{(-1)^{n-1}\frac{1}{n}x^n} . We can rewrite this fraction algebraically and simplify it consderably. Grouping the similar terms between the numerator and denominator, we see
r_n(x) = \frac{(-1)^{n}}{(-1)^{n-1}} \cdot \frac{n}{n+1} \cdot \frac{x^{n+1}}{x^n} , which allows us to simplify and conclude that
r_n(x) = (-1) \cdot \frac{n}{n+1} \cdot x . This tells us the series T_f(x) is not geometric since the ratio depends on n. For example, if we take n = 2, we have
r_2(x) = -\frac{2}{3}x , which is the ratio between the third and second terms of T_f(x), while
r_3(x) = -\frac{3}{4}x
is the ratio between the fourth and third terms. Since the ratio r_n(x) depends on n, the series lacks a common ratio between terms.

However, as n gets large, the series T_f(x) is almost geometric. This is because the quantity \frac{n}{n+1} approaches 1 as n increases without bound, and therefore for large n,
r_n(x) \approx -x . This suggests that the series T_f(x) converges for |r_n(x)| \approx |-x| = |x| \lt 1, since the series is very close to being geometric with a common ratio -x. Graphical evidence supports the conclusion that for |x| \lt 1, the series T_f(x) converges in the same way that a geometric one would, and also that the interval of convervence is -1 \lt x \lt 1. In **FIGURE**, we see plots of f(x) = \ln(1+x), T_{10}(x) = x - \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \cdots - \frac{1}{10}x^{10}, and T_{20}(x) = x - \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \cdots - \frac{1}{20}x^{20}. ****

In FIGURE we see that on roughly the interval -0.8 \lt x \lt 0.8, f(x), T_{10}(x), and T_{20}(x) are nearly indistinguishable. Furthermore, we see that if we widen the interval to -0.9 \lt x \lt 0.9, T_{20}(x) remains a very good approximation of f(x). For example, we can do some computations and find that
f(-0.8) - T_{10}(-0.8) \approx -0.030563, f(-0.8) - T_{20}(-0.8) \approx -0.001091 , and
f(-0.9) - T_{10}(-0.9) \approx -0.183837, f(-0.8) - T_{20}(-0.8) \approx -0.032564 . Increasing the degree of the approximation further allows us to do a bit better, but since f(x) = \ln(1+x) is undefined and has a vertical asymptote at x = -1, there won't be any polynomial function that can accurately approximate f(x) at x = -1. Thus, it appears to be the case that T_f(x) converges for x-values that satisfy -1 \lt x \lt 1, and on that interval the Taylor series converges to f(x) = \ln(1+x).

subsection.p:
From Example, we see a striking result: it appears that for x-values where the Taylor series T_f(x) of f(x) = \ln(1+x) converges to a finite value, the Taylor series actually equals the function f. Said differently, it appears that
\ln(1+x) = x - \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{3}x^3 - \cdots + (-1)^{n-1}\frac{1}{n}x^n + \cdots
for x-values that satisfy -1 \lt x \lt 1. This result is analogous to Equation, but is different in the sense that the Taylor series for \ln(1+x) is not geometric. We next introduce a more formal way to test how geometric a Taylor series is in an effort to understand where the Taylor series converges.

assemblage.title: The Ratio Test
assemblage.p: Consider an infinite series of the form T(x) = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} c_n (x-a)^k, where a is any real number.
